content: I am a PhD student working on statistical transcriptomics methods in Sandrine Dudoit’s lab. I am collaborating with the He Lab, and recently joined a team in Berkeley lead by John Ngai as part of the NIH Brain Inititative, to apply those statistical and computing methods to current biological questions. I am also working on a joint project between Whole Biome and Laurent Jacob, developing metagenomics-related methodologies.

content:
Modelization of single-cell gene expression along a timeline Report abstract The explosion of genomic data over the past two decades created a need for new and more performing tools. One type of data in particular, Single-cell RNA Sequencing data, allow for a cell-level detection of biological patterns but technical limitations add lots of noise sources to the data. In particular, some counts are dropped and appear as zeros, even thought the gene is expressed in the cell. Here, we present a new method to detect dropouts in cases of development trajectories. Our various model all improve substantially on random guesses and offer a computationally-efficient way to infer correct gene expression patterns over time. The GitHub containing all our scripts is available online at the following address: https://github.com/HectorRDB/CS289_Final_Project
Spring 2018
Group members: Daniel Amar, Ariane Lozac’hmeur, Hector Roux de Bézieux & Alexandre Vincent
 The project proposal is available on Overleaf and may be read here. The project report is available on Overleaf and may be read here.

[THIS IS A DRAFT] Overview Recently, a new member joined the Dudoit lab and I had to think on which ressources to point him to so that he could start getting up to speed with on the field. I think that the ressources I recommand fall into 4 broad (and largely overlapping) categories:
 Biology and techniques How to find, acess and pre-process data (including how to use bio-informatics tools) Statistics How to use all of the above to conduct an analysis (with - of course - a strong emphasis on R tools)  I’ll therefore try to list ressources to help in all subjects. This will be a mix of (scientific) papers, books, package vignette, personal tutorials, video…
If you find any other ressources, feel free to contact me.
Before we begin Those ressources assume that you have at least a basic knowledge of R, statistics and biology. For R otherwise, I recommand (and I am far from the only one) Garrett Grolemund & Hadley Wickham’s R For Data Science. Any suggestions for biology and statistics introductory guides are weclome.
Biology and techniques Koen review Central dogma Illumina video Sanger sequencing
Getting your hands on data A first - and excellent - ressource of good pre-processed data is the recount2 project.
